title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — In the crucible of a tight Eastern Conference battle, one man refused to let his team lose. Reggie Miller, with a singular, breathtaking performance, authored a legendary chapter in the storied Celtics-Pacers rivalry, carrying the Indiana Pacers to a dramatic 97-94 victory over the Boston Celtics in 1997.

From the opening tip, this was Miller’s game. While the Celtics relied on a balanced attack, Indiana’s offense ran through its sharpshooter. Miller was a study in offensive perfection, pouring in a game-high 39 points on an impossibly efficient 12-of-19 shooting from the field. He was a menace from beyond the arc, draining five three-pointers, and a perfect 10-for-10 from the charity stripe, each free throw a nail in the Celtics’ coffin.

Boston, led by Rick Fox’s 20 points, stayed within striking distance throughout, their defense scrambling to find an answer for the relentless Miller. But on this night, there was none. Every Celtic run was answered by a cold-blooded jumper, a slicing drive, or a clutch three from the Pacers’ icon. The final minutes were a masterclass in closing, with Miller’s unerring free throws sealing the hard-fought win and extinguishing Boston’s hopes.

The final stat line was more than just a win; it was a historic, virtuoso performance. In a game where every possession mattered, Reggie Miller didn’t just lead his team—he *was* the team, delivering one of the most memorable and efficient scoring nights of his Hall of Fame career and sending a clear message to the league.
